bestBHT.bht: Jesus, the carpenter, performed ordinary carpentry work making plows and yokes among men. His lack of ability to perform miracles was not because He was powerless, but because of the people's faithlessness. He often required faith from recipients, and without it, help could not be given. The fact that Jesus was rejected even by His own brothers, who disbelieved His Messianic claims, is a sad reality. This highlights the significance of His humble life as a carpenter, setting an example of industry and diligence.

Henry Alford: For He wrought, while among men, the ordinary works of a carpenter, to wit, ploughs and yokes.
The want of ability spoken of is not absolute, but relative: 'not because He was powerless, but because they were faithless.'
In most cases of human infirmity, it was our Lord's practice to require faith in the recipient of aid: and that being wanting, the help could not be given.
Marvin Vincent: The carpenter. This word 'throws the only flash which falls on the continuous tenor of the first thirty years, from infancy to manhood, of the life of Christ'" (Farrar, "Messages of the Books").
Philip Schaff: All Jewish young men learned a trade.
The Son of man would doubtless share in the primal curse.
Archibald T. Robertson: This word carpenter 'throws the only flash which falls on the continuous tenor of the first thirty years from infancy to manhood, of the life of Christ' (Farrar).
He became--πετρα σκανδαλου (1 Peter 2:7; 1 Peter 2:8; Romans 9:33) to those who disbelieved.
This was the saddest part of it all, that his own brothers in his own home disbelieved his Messianic claims.
John Gill: such may Christ be reasonably thought to be, since his father was; and which business he might follow, partly through the meanness and poverty of his parents; and partly that he might set an example of industry and diligence
the Jews ought not to have flouted Christ with this trade of a carpenter, since, according to them, it was necessary that a carpenter, in some cases, should be a regular priest
they could by no means think of him as the Messiah, who made so contemptible a figure, and was brought up in such a low way of life
John Wesley: Is not this the carpenter? — There can be no doubt, but in his youth he wrought with his supposed father Joseph.

bhtAttempts.bht: Jesus, known as the carpenter, performed ordinary carpentry work such as making plows and yokes among men. However, His ability to perform miracles was hindered by the lack of faith from those around Him. Jesus often required faith from recipients before providing aid, and without it, help could not be given. His own brothers in His own home even disbelieved His Messianic claims, showing the sad reality that those closest to Him rejected Him. It is significant that Jesus, the Son of man, shared in the primal curse and worked as a carpenter, as it sheds light on the continuous thirty years of His life leading up to His ministry.

Jesus, the carpenter, performed ordinary carpentry work making plows and yokes among men. His inability to perform miracles was due to the lack of faith from those around Him. He often required faith from recipients to give aid. Even His own brothers disbelieved His Messianic claims, which was the saddest part. This sheds light on the continuous thirty years of His life. His role as the Son of man who shared in the primal curse is significant, as it shows the necessity and example of industry and diligence.

His lack of ability to perform miracles was not because He was powerless, but because of the people's faithlessness. He often required faith from recipients, and without it, help could not be given. The fact that Jesus was rejected even by His own brothers, who disbelieved His Messianic claims, is a sad reality. This highlights the significance of His humble life as a carpenter, setting an example of industry and diligence.

Jesus, the carpenter, performed ordinary carpentry work making plows and yokes among men. The lack of ability to perform miracles was due to the people's faithlessness. Faith was crucial for Him to provide help. Even His own brothers disbelieved His Messianic claims, a sad part of His journey. His humble life as a carpenter sheds light on his continuous thirty years, setting an example of industry and diligence.

Jesus often required faith from recipients before providing aid, and without it, help could not be given. His own brothers in His own home even disbelieved His Messianic claims, showing the sad reality that those closest to Him rejected Him. It is significant that Jesus, the Son of man, shared in the primal curse and worked as a carpenter, as it sheds light on the continuous thirty years of His life leading up to His ministry.
